conditions", "Macular degeneration", "Eye", "Visual impairment and blindness"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "
  • Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a common condition that affects the middle part of your vision. It usually first affects people in their 50s and 60s.
  • It doesn't cause total blindness. But it can make everyday activities like reading and recognising faces difficult.
  • Without treatment, your vision may get worse. This can happen gradually over several years ("dry AMD"), or quickly over a few weeks or months ("wet AMD").
  • The exact cause is unknown. It's been linked to smoking, high blood pressure, being overweight and having a family history of AMD.
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "What is AMD?"}
Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia", "alternateName": ["Anaemia (vitamin B12 or folate deficiency)"]}, "description": "Read about vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia, which occurs when a lack of vitamin B12 or folate causes the body to produce abnormally large red blood cells.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/", "lastReviewed": ["2019-05-23T00:00:00+00:00", "2022-05-23T00:00:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/", "name": "Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-17T10:43:11+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [{"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/#overview", "description": "Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia is where your body makes abnormally large red blood cells that cannot function properly.", "text": "

Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia can cause a wide range of symptoms, including extreme tiredness, a sore red tongue and muscle weakness.

Causes of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia include a problem with your immune system and a lack of vitamins in your diet.

The main treatments for vitamin B12 and folate deficiency anaemia are vitamin injections or tablets.

"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "symptoms", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/#symptoms", "description": "Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia can cause a wide range of symptoms, including extreme tiredness, a sore red tongue and muscle weakness.", "text": "

Vitamin B12 and folate perform several important functions in the body, including keeping the nervous system healthy.

A deficiency in either of these vitamins can cause a wide range of problems, including:

  • extreme tiredness
  • a lack of energy
  • pins and needles (paraesthesia)
  • a sore and red tongue
  • mouth ulcers
  • muscle weakness
  • disturbed vision
  • psychological problems, which may include depression\u00a0and\u00a0confusion
  • problems with\u00a0memory, understanding and judgement

Some of these problems can also happen if you have a deficiency in vitamin B12 or folate but do not have anaemia.

", "title": "Symptoms of vitamin B12\u00a0or folate deficiency"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "causes", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/#causes", "description": "Causes of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia include a problem with your immune system and a lack of vitamins in your diet.", "text": "

There are a number of problems that can lead to a vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

These include:

  • pernicious anaemia\u00a0\u2013\u00a0where your immune system attacks healthy cells in your stomach, preventing your body absorbing vitamin B12 from the food you eat; this\u00a0is the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency in the UK
  • a lack of these vitamins in your diet\u00a0\u2013\u00a0this is uncommon, but can happen if you have a vegan diet, follow a fad diet or have a generally poor diet for a long time
  • medicine\u00a0\u2013\u00a0certain medicines, including anticonvulsants and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), can affect how much of these vitamins your body absorbs

Both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency are more common in older people, affecting around 1 in 10 people aged 75 or over and 1 in 20 people aged 65 to 74.

", "title": "Causes of a vitamin B12 or folate deficiency"}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "treatments_overview", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/#treatments-summary", "description": "The main treatments for vitamin B12 and folate deficiency anaemia are vitamin injections or tablets.", "text": "", "title": ""}, {"@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "other_treatments", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/#treatments-other", "description": "The main treatments for vitamin B12 and folate deficiency anaemia are vitamin injections or tablets.", "text": "

Most cases of vitamin B12 and folate deficiency can be\u00a0easily treated with injections or tablets to replace the\u00a0missing vitamins.

Vitamin B12 supplements are usually given by injection at first.

Then, depending on whether your B12 deficiency is related to your diet, you'll either require B12 tablets between meals\u00a0or regular injections.

These treatments may be needed for the rest of your life.

Folic acid tablets are used to restore folate levels. These usually need to be taken for 4 months.

In some cases, improving your diet can help treat the condition and prevent it coming back.

Vitamin B12 is found in meat, fish, eggs,\u00a0dairy products, yeast extract (such as Marmite) and specially fortified foods.

The best sources of folate include green vegetables, such as broccoli, brussels sprouts and peas.

", "title": "Treating vitamin B12 or folate\u00a0deficiency anaemia"}], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/symptoms/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "Symptoms"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/causes/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Causes"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/diagnosis/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 3, "name": "Diagnosis"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/treatment/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 4, "name": "Treatment"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/complications/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 5, "name": "Complications"}], "keywords": ["Vitamin and mineral preparations", "Blood", "Vitamin B12 deficiency", "Anaemia", "Vitamins and minerals", "Pernicious anaemia"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vitamin B12 or B9 (commonly called folate) deficiency anaemia occurs\u00a0when a lack of vitamin B12 or folate causes the body to produce abnormally large red blood cells that cannot function properly.

Red blood cells carry oxygen around the body using a substance called haemoglobin.

Anaemia is the general term\u00a0for having either fewer red blood cells than normal or having an abnormally low amount of haemoglobin in each red blood cell.

There are several different types of anaemia and each one has a different cause.

For example, iron deficiency anaemia happens\u00a0when the body does not contain enough iron.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Symptoms of vitamin B12\u00a0or folate deficiency", "text": "Symptoms of vitamin B12\u00a0or folate deficiency", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Vitamin B12 and folate perform several important functions in the body, including keeping the nervous system healthy.

A deficiency in either of these vitamins can cause a wide range of problems, including:

  • extreme tiredness
  • a lack of energy
  • pins and needles (paraesthesia)
  • a sore and red tongue
  • mouth ulcers
  • muscle weakness
  • disturbed vision
  • psychological problems, which may include depression\u00a0and\u00a0confusion
  • problems with\u00a0memory, understanding and judgement

Some of these problems can also happen if you have a deficiency in vitamin B12 or folate but do not have anaemia.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to see a GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see a GP

See a GP if you think you may have a vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

These conditions can often be diagnosed based on your symptoms and the results of a\u00a0blood test.

It's important for vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia to be diagnosed and treated as soon as possible.

This is because although many of the symptoms improve with treatment, some problems caused by the condition can be irreversible.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of a vitamin B12 or folate deficiency", "text": "Causes of a vitamin B12 or folate deficiency", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

There are a number of problems that can lead to a vitamin B12 or folate deficiency.

These include:

  • pernicious anaemia\u00a0\u2013\u00a0where your immune system attacks healthy cells in your stomach, preventing your body absorbing vitamin B12 from the food you eat; this\u00a0is the most common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency in the UK
  • a lack of these vitamins in your diet\u00a0\u2013\u00a0this is uncommon, but can happen if you have a vegan diet, follow a fad diet or have a generally poor diet for a long time
  • medicine\u00a0\u2013\u00a0certain medicines, including anticonvulsants and proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), can affect how much of these vitamins your body absorbs

Both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency are more common in older people, affecting around 1 in 10 people aged 75 or over and 1 in 20 people aged 65 to 74.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treating vitamin B12 or folate\u00a0deficiency anaemia", "text": "Treating vitamin B12 or folate\u00a0deficiency anaemia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Most cases of vitamin B12 and folate deficiency can be\u00a0easily treated with injections or tablets to replace the\u00a0missing vitamins.

Vitamin B12 supplements are usually given by injection at first.

Then, depending on whether your B12 deficiency is related to your diet, you'll either require B12 tablets between meals\u00a0or regular injections.

These treatments may be needed for the rest of your life.

Folic acid tablets are used to restore folate levels. These usually need to be taken for 4 months.

In some cases, improving your diet can help treat the condition and prevent it coming back.

Vitamin B12 is found in meat, fish, eggs,\u00a0dairy products, yeast extract (such as Marmite) and specially fortified foods.

The best sources of folate include green vegetables, such as broccoli, brussels sprouts and peas.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Complications of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Complications of vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia

Although it's uncommon, vitamin B12 or folate deficiency (with or without anaemia) can lead to complications, particularly if you have been deficient in vitamin B12 or folate for some time.

Potential complications can include:

  • problems with the nervous system
  • temporary infertility
  • heart conditions
  • pregnancy complications and birth defects

Adults with severe anaemia are also at risk of developing heart failure.

Some\u00a0complications improve with appropriate treatment, but others, such as problems with the nervous system, can be permanent.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": []}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Abortion:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Abortion", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Abortion", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out what an abortion involves, how you can get one on the NHS, and what support is available to help you make a decision.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/abortion/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-04-24T11:13:00+00:00", "2023-04-24T11:13:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/abortion/", "name": "Abortion", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-12-21T16:11:12+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/abortion/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Abortion", "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/abortion/what-happens/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 1, "name": "What happens"}, {"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/abortion/risks/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 2, "name": "Risks"}], "keywords": ["Termination", "Abortion"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

An abortion is a procedure to end a pregnancy.

It's also sometimes known as a termination of pregnancy.

The pregnancy is ended either by taking medicines or having a surgical procedure.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Coronavirus update

Abortion services are still open. You can self-refer by contacting an abortion provider directly.

They can explain how their services are working at the moment.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "How to get an abortion", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Abortions can only be carried out under the care of an NHS hospital or a licensed clinic, and are usually available free of charge on the NHS.

There are 3 main ways to get an abortion on the NHS:

  • you can self-refer by contacting an abortion provider directly \u2013 the British Pregnancy Advisory Service (BPAS), MSI Reproductive Choices UK, the National Unplanned Pregnancy Advisory Service (NUPAS) or your local NHS sexual health website can tell you about eligibility and services in your area
  • speak to a GP and ask for a referral to an abortion service \u2013 the GP should refer you to another doctor if he or she has any objections to abortion
  • contact a sexual health clinic (sometimes called family planning or GUM (genitourinary medicine) clinics) and ask for a referral to an abortion service

Waiting times can vary, but you should not have to wait more than 2 weeks from when you (or a doctor) first contact an abortion provider to having an abortion.

You can also pay for an abortion privately (not on the NHS) if you prefer. Costs for private abortions vary depending on the stage of pregnancy and the method used to carry out the procedure.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "When an abortion can be carried out", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Most abortions in England, Wales and Scotland are carried out before 24 weeks of pregnancy.

They can be carried out after 24 weeks in very limited circumstances \u2013 for example, if the mother's life is at risk or the child would be born with a severe disability.

Most abortion services will ask to perform an ultrasound scan to work out how many weeks pregnant you are. The length of pregnancy is calculated from the first day of your last period.

Abortions are safer the earlier they're carried out. Getting advice early on will give you more time to make a decision if you're unsure.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Deciding to have an abortion", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

The decision to have an abortion is yours alone.

Some women may be certain they want to have an abortion, while others may find it more difficult to make a decision.

All women requesting an abortion can discuss their options with, and receive support from, a trained pregnancy counsellor if they wish.

Impartial information and support are available from:

  • your GP or another doctor at your GP practice
  • a counselling service at the abortion clinic
  • organisations such as Brook (for under-25s), BPAS, MSI Reproductive Choices UK and NUPAS

You may also want to speak to your partner, friends or family, but you do not have to. They do not have a say in your decision.

If you do not want to tell anyone, your details will be kept confidential.

If you're under 16, your parents do not usually need to be told. The doctor or nurse may encourage you to tell a parent, carer or other adult you trust, but they will not make you.

There are organisations, usually known as crisis pregnancy centres, that offer counselling around pregnancy. They do not refer people for abortion, and may not offer balanced or accurate advice.

If you go to a place that offers pregnancy counselling and you're not sure if they will refer you for an abortion, ask if they refer people for an abortion.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "What happens during an abortion", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Before having an abortion, you'll have an appointment to talk about your decision and what happens next.

Whenever possible, you should be given a choice of how you would like the abortion to be carried out.

There are 2 options:

  • medical abortion ("abortion pill") \u2013 you take 2 medicines, usually 24 to 48 hours apart, to induce an abortion
  • surgical abortion \u2013 you have a procedure to remove the pregnancy and normally go home soon afterwards

After an abortion, you'll probably need to take things easy for a few days. It's likely you'll have some discomfort and vaginal bleeding for up to 2 weeks.

Read more about how an abortion is carried out.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Risks of an abortion", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Abortion is a safe procedure. Abortions are safest, and happen with less pain and bleeding, when carried out as early as possible in pregnancy.

Most women will not experience any problems, but there is a small risk of complications, such as:

  • infection of the womb (uterus)
  • some of the pregnancy remaining in the womb
  • excessive bleeding
  • damage to the womb or entrance of the womb (cervix)

If complications do occur, you may need further treatment, including surgery.

Having an abortion will not affect your chances of becoming pregnant again and having normal pregnancies in the future.

You may be able to get pregnant immediately after an abortion. You should use contraception if you do not want to get pregnant.

Read more about the risks of abortion.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}], "alternativeHeadline": "Overview"}
Bird flu:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Bird flu", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Bird flu", "alternateName": ["Avian flu"]}, "description": "Bird flu, or avian flu, is an infectious viral illness that spreads among birds. In rare cases, it can affect humans.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bird-flu/", "lastReviewed": ["2018-05-18T06:49:00+00:00", "2021-05-18T06:49:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bird-flu/", "name": "Bird flu", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2019-02-04T11:56:27+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/bird-flu/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Bird flu"}], "keywords": ["Avian flu", "Bird flu"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bird flu, or avian flu, is an infectious type of influenza that spreads among birds. In rare cases, it can affect humans.

There are lots of different strains of bird flu virus. Most of them don't infect humans. But there are 4 strains that have caused concern in recent years:

  • H5N1 (since 1997)
  • H7N9 (since 2013)
  • H5N6 (since 2014)
  • H5N8 (since 2016)

Although H5N1, H7N9 and H5N6 don't infect people easily and aren't usually spread from human to human, several people have been infected around the world, leading to a number of deaths. H5N8 has not infected any humans worldwide to date.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Bird flu in the UK", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Bird flu in the UK

No humans have been infected with H5N1, H7N9, H5N6 or H5N8 bird flu in the UK – this includes the type of H5N6 virus recently found in humans in China. Plans are in place to manage any suspected cases.

H5N8 bird flu has been found in some wild birds and poultry in the UK. H5N6 has also been found in some wild birds in the UK but is a different strain to that seen in China.

You can read the latest bird flu updates on GOV.UK.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "How bird flu spreads to humans", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How bird flu spreads to humans

Bird flu is spread by close contact with an infected bird (dead or alive).

This includes:

  • touching infected birds
  • touching droppings or bedding
  • killing or preparing infected poultry for cooking

Markets where live birds are sold can also be a source of bird flu. Avoid visiting these markets if you're travelling to countries that have had an outbreak of bird flu.

You can't catch bird flu through eating fully cooked poultry or eggs, even in areas with an outbreak of bird flu.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Things you can do to prevent bird flu", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things you can do to prevent bird flu

If you're visiting a foreign country that's had an outbreak you should:

  • wash your hands often with warm water and soap, especially before and after handling food, in particular raw poultry
  • use different utensils for cooked and raw meat
  • make sure meat is cooked until steaming hot
  • avoid contact with live birds and poultry

What not to do:

  • do not go near or touch bird droppings or sick or dead birds
  • do not go to live animal markets or poultry farms
  • do not bring any live birds or poultry back to the UK, including feathers
  • do not eat undercooked or raw poultry or duck
  • do not eat raw eggs

There is no bird flu vaccine

The seasonal flu vaccine doesn't protect against bird flu.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Symptoms", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Symptoms of bird flu

The main symptoms of bird flu can appear very quickly and include:

  • a very high temperature or feeling hot or shivery
  • aching muscles
  • headache
  • a cough

Other early symptoms may include:

  • diarrhoea
  • sickness
  • stomach pain
  • chest pain
  • bleeding from the nose and gums
  • conjunctivitis

It usually takes 3 to 5 days for the first symptoms to appear after you've been infected.

Within days of symptoms appearing, it's possible to develop more severe complications such as pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome.

Getting treatment quickly, using antiviral medicine, may prevent complications and reduce the risk of developing severe illness.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to seek medical advice

Call a GP or NHS 111 if you experience any symptoms of bird flu and have visited an area affected by bird flu in the past 10 days.

Your symptoms can be checked over the phone.

If you're abroad

Get medical help straight away if you get the symptoms of bird flu.

Contact your travel insurance company if you need advice about where to get help.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What a doctor can do

Tell the doctor if you have:

  • recently travelled to an area affected by bird flu and if you've been close (within 1 metre) to live or dead birds
  • had close contact (touching or speaking distance) with anyone who has a severe respiratory illness
  • had contact with anyone who died unexpectedly and was from an area that had an outbreak

These tests can be done to confirm bird flu:

  • a nose and throat swab to see if they contain the virus
  • if you're coughing up phlegm this may be tested for the virus

If the tests are normal, it's unlikely you have bird flu.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Treatment", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Treatment for bird flu

If it's thought you might have symptoms of bird flu you'll be advised to stay at home, or you'll be cared for in hospital in isolation from other patients.

You may be given an antiviral medicine such as oseltamivir (Tamiflu) or zanamivir (Relenza).

Antiviral medicines help reduce the severity of the condition, prevent complications and improve the chances of survival.

They are also sometimes given to people who have been in close contact with infected birds, or those who have had contact with infected people, for example family or healthcare staff.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": null, "text": "Reporting suspected cases of bird flu", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Reporting suspected cases of bird flu

Bird flu is a notifiable disease in animals, so you should report any suspected case in animals to the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA), even if you're not sure.

Call the Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) helpline on 03459 33 55 77 if you find dead wild birds.

To prevent infection it is important not to touch or pick up any dead or visibly sick birds that you find.

You can read more about notifiable diseases in animals and how to spot bird flu and what to do if you suspect it on the GOV.UK website.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Antifungal medicines:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Antifungal medicines", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Antifungal medicines", "alternateName": []}, "description": "Find out about antifungal medicines, which are used to treat fungal infections such as thrush and athlete's foot.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/antifungal-medicines/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-07-27T07:05:00+00:00", "2023-07-27T07:05:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/antifungal-medicines/", "name": "Antifungal medicines", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-08-06T16:39:00+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/antifungal-medicines/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Antifungal medicines"}], "keywords": ["Antifungal medicines", "Antifungals", "Antifungal drugs"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Antifungal medicines are used to treat fungal infections, which most commonly affect your skin, hair and nails.

You can get some antifungal medicines from a pharmacy without needing a GP prescription.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Infections antifungals can treat", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Infections antifungals can treat

Fungal infections commonly treated with antifungals include:

  • ringworm
  • athlete's foot
  • fungal nail infection
  • vaginal thrush
  • some types of severe dandruff

Some fungal infections can grow inside the body and need to be treated in hospital.

Examples include:

  • aspergillosis, which affects the lungs
  • fungal meningitis, which affects the brain

You're more at risk of getting one of these more serious fungal infections if you have a weakened immune system \u2013 for example, if you're taking medicines to suppress your immune system.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Types of antifungal medicines", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Types of antifungal medicines

You can get antifungal medicines as:

  • a cream, gel, ointment or spray
  • a capsule, tablet or liquid
  • an injection
  • a pessary: a small and soft tablet you put inside the vagina

Common names for antifungal medicines include:

  • clotrimazole
  • econazole
  • miconazole
  • terbinafine
  • fluconazole
  • ketoconazole
  • amphotericin
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "How antifungal medicines work", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

How antifungal medicines work

Antifungal medicines work by either:

  • killing the fungus
  • preventing the fungus from growing
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to see a pharmacist or GP", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

When to see a pharmacist or GP

See a pharmacist or GP if you think you have a fungal infection. They can advise you on which antifungal medicine is best for you.

If you take too much antifungal medicine, call 111 or speak to a pharmacist or GP.

If you're advised to go to hospital, take the medicine's packaging with you so the healthcare professionals who treat you know what you've taken.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Things to consider when using antifungal medicines", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Things to consider when using antifungal medicines

Before taking antifungal medicines, speak to a pharmacist or GP about:

  • any existing conditions or allergies that may affect your treatment for fungal infection
  • the possible side effects of antifungal medicines
  • whether the antifungal medicine may interact with other medicines you may already be taking
  • whether your antifungal medicine is suitable to take during pregnancy or while breastfeeding \u2013 many are not suitable

You can also check the patient information leaflet that comes with your antifungal medicine for more information.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 6, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Side effects of antifungal medicines", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Side effects of antifungal medicines

Antifungal medicines may cause side effects. These are usually mild and do not last long.

They can include:

  • itching or burning
  • redness
  • feeling sick
  • tummy (abdominal) pain
  • diarrhoea
  • a rash

Occasionally, antifungal medicines may cause a more severe reaction, such as:

  • an allergic reaction \u2013 your face, neck or tongue may swell and you may have difficulty breathing
  • a severe skin reaction \u2013 such as peeling or blistering skin
  • liver damage (very rarely) \u2013 you may have loss of appetite, vomiting, nausea, jaundice, dark pee or pale poo, tiredness or weakness

Stop using the medicine if you have these severe side effects, and see a GP or pharmacist to find an alternative.

If you're having difficulty breathing, go to A&E or call 999.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 7, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Reporting side effects", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Reporting side effects

If you think a medicine has made you unwell, you can report this side effect through the Yellow Card Scheme.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 8, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Antifungal medicines for children", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Antifungal medicines for children

Some antifungal medicines can be used to treat children and babies \u2013 for example, miconazole oral gel can be used for oral thrush in babies.

But different doses are usually needed for children of different ages. Speak to a pharmacist or GP for more advice.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
Lost or changed sense of smell:
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Lost or changed sense of smell", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Lost or changed sense of smell", "alternateName": ["Anosmia", "Sense of smell (lost/changed)"]}, "description": "A change in your sense of smell can be unpleasant and affect how things taste. But it is not usually serious and may get better in a few weeks or months.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/lost-or-changed-sense-smell/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-12-11T11:50:00+00:00", "2023-12-11T11:50:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/lost-or-changed-sense-smell/", "name": "Lost or changed sense of smell", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-12-22T12:53:24+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/lost-or-changed-sense-smell/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Lost or changed sense of smell"}], "keywords": [], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

A change in your sense of smell can be unpleasant and affect how things taste. But it is not usually serious and may get better in a few weeks or months.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Coronavirus

A loss or change to your sense of smell or taste could be coronavirus (COVID-19).

Get advice about coronavirus symptoms and what to do

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Causes of lost or changed sense of smell", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Changes in sense of smell are most often caused by:

  • a cold or flu
  • sinusitis (sinus infection)
  • an allergy, like hay fever
  • growths in your nose (nasal polyps)

These can cause:

  • loss of smell (anosmia)
  • smelling things that are not there (phantosmia), like smoke or burnt toast
  • reduced sense of smell (hyposmia)
  • the smell of things to change (parosmia)
", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Information", "identifier": "3", "text": "

It's also common to lose some of your sense of smell as you get older.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 3, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Cleaning inside your nose can help", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Rinsing the inside of your nose with a saltwater solution may help if your sense of smell is affected by an infection or allergy.

You can make a saltwater solution at home.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Reveal", "subjectOf": "How to clean your nose with a saltwater solution", "identifier": "11", "mainEntity": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "
  1. Boil a pint of water, then leave it to cool.
  2. Mix a teaspoon of salt and a teaspoon of baking soda (bicarbonate of soda) into the water.
  3. Wash your hands.
  4. Stand over a sink, cup the palm of 1 hand and pour a small amount of the solution into it.
  5. Sniff some of the solution up 1 nostril at a time and let it run out of your nose. It might help to hold your other nostril closed with your finger as you sniff.
  6. Repeat these steps a few times to see if it helps.

You do not need to use all of the solution, but make a fresh batch each day \u2013 do not reuse any left over from the day before.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Some pharmacies sell sachets you can use to make a saltwater solution and devices to help you rinse your nose.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Find a service", "identifier": "2", "text": "

Find a pharmacy

\n"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 4, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if your sense of smell does not go back to normal in a few weeks

They'll check for any obvious causes, such as sinusitis or nasal polyps.

They may refer you to a specialist for tests if they're not sure what the problem is.

"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 5, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "Treatment for lost or changed sense of smell", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Your sense of smell may go back to normal in a few weeks or months.

Treating the cause might help. For example, steroid nasal sprays or drops might help if you have sinusitis or nasal polyps.

A treatment called smell training can also help some people. To find out more about smell training, see:

  • AbScent: smell training
  • Fifth Sense: smell testing and training

Sometimes changes in sense of smell can not be treated and may be permanent.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Important

If you have lost your sense of smell, you may not be able to smell things like gas leaks, fires and food that's gone off.

Fifth Sense has some safety advice if you have anosmia.

"}]}]}
Memory loss (amnesia):
{"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "MedicalWebPage", "name": "Memory loss (amnesia)", "copyrightHolder": {"name": "Crown Copyright", "@type": "Organization"}, "license": "https://developer.api.nhs.uk/terms", "author": {"url": "https://www.nhs.uk", "logo": "https://www.nhs.uk/nhscwebservices/documents/logo1.jpg", "email": "nhswebsite.servicedesk@nhs.net", "@type": "Organization", "name": "NHS website"}, "about": {"@type": "MedicalCondition", "name": "Memory loss (amnesia)", "alternateName": ["Amnesia"]}, "description": "NHS information about memory loss (amnesia), including advice about what to do if you have problems with your memory and what the cause might be.", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/memory-loss-amnesia/", "lastReviewed": ["2020-10-09T15:31:00+00:00", "2023-10-09T15:31:00+00:00"], "breadcrumb": {"@context": "http://schema.org", "@type": "BreadcrumbList", "itemListElement": [{"@type": "ListItem", "position": 0, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/", "name": "Health A to Z", "genre": "condition"}}, {"@type": "ListItem", "position": 1, "item": {"@id": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/memory-loss-amnesia/", "name": "Memory loss (amnesia)", "genre": "condition"}}]}, "dateModified": "2020-10-19T17:12:03+00:00", "genre": "condition", "hasPart": [], "relatedLink": [{"@type": "LinkRole", "url": "https://api.nhs.uk/conditions/memory-loss-amnesia/", "linkRelationship": "Navigation", "position": 0, "name": "Memory loss (amnesia)"}], "keywords": ["Dementia", "Head injuries", "Stress", "Stroke", "Older people", "Depression", "Memory problems", "Underactive thyroid", "Anxiety", "Alzheimer's disease"], "mainEntityOfPage": [{"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Most people forget things from time to time, but see a GP if you keep having problems with your memory. It could be caused by something that can be treated.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "When to get medical help", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Primary care", "identifier": "5", "text": "

See a GP if:

  • memory problems are affecting your day-to-day life

It's probably nothing serious, but it's best to get checked because any treatment you need may work better if it's started early.

"}, {"position": 1, "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "Callout", "identifier": "4", "text": "

Concern for a relative

If you're worried about an older relative who's becoming increasingly forgetful, speak to a GP about whether it could be a sign of dementia.

"}, {"position": 2, "identifier": "1", "text": "

What happens at your appointment

The GP will ask you some questions to try to find the cause of your memory problems.

It might be useful to bring someone else with you who can help describe the problems you're having.

The GP may refer you to a memory specialist for an in-depth assessment. Further tests, such as scans, may also sometimes be needed.

Any treatment that's recommended will depend on the cause of your memory problems.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}, {"identifier": "0", "name": "section heading", "position": 2, "@type": "WebPageElement", "headline": "", "text": "Causes", "mainEntityOfPage": [{"position": 0, "identifier": "1", "text": "

Causes of memory loss

Memory loss can just be a natural part of getting older.

Sometimes it may be caused by something common and treatable like:

  • stress
  • anxiety or depression
  • sleeping problems (insomnia)

Occasionally, memory loss can be a sign of something more serious, such as dementia.

Do not try to self-diagnose the cause of your memory loss \u2013 always see a GP.

", "@type": "WebPageElement", "name": "markdown"}]}]}
